speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Clark versus Arizona. Mr. Goldberg.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It was excluded with respect to mens rea, but, of course, all of the evidence came in with respect to the insanity defense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- the State telling us -- and we'll ask the State when they argue -- but is the State telling us that it has defined "intent" in a particular way for this, so that "intent" is just having the purpose to cause the result --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- and, therefore, that this testimony is irrelevant? Is that the State's argument, as you understand it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, do you take that -- please.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you make of the very name that the State gave, not acquitted by reason -- not not-guilty by reason of insanity, but guilty, except insane. Guilty of what? Guilty of the charge. And the charge is first-degree murder. So, even if insanity is found, apparently that's defined to be "guilty of the charge, except insane," therefore not subject to criminal punishment.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But the lay -- I'm sorry. That was my question. The lay --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- witnesses still talked about his mental state, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- what they have here -- the -- what the SG says -- which seemed right to me, and I would like you to explain why it wasn't -- is that as far as the insanity defense is concerned, that everyone in Arizona agrees that you consider whether he knows right from wrong in respect to this act. Thus, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 if he thinks the truckdriver is an alien, or he thinks he's an animal, and has a serious mental problem in knowing what's going on, that comes right in, as it did here, because it's relevant to whether he knew it was right or wrong to shoot this person. And, therefore, once I read that, I thought there is not, at least in this case, a question of whether the insanity defense is complete, because it is. Everything that you wanted to introduce was introduced. And, indeed, it was considered, properly, under the insanity defense. And if you had convinced the jury, you would -- or the -- I guess, the jury -- you would have won on that. Now, am I -- what's wrong with what I've just said?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but I'm interested in Arizona, remember. I'm not -- what I'm interested in is whether if you say, "Judge, I am going to prove the following. My client knows right from wrong, in general, but he thought that the truckdriver was a wild animal, and that delusion meant that he is so insane, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 he could not have formed the necessary intent." The judge replies, "You can bring that in, because if he thought the driver was a mental -- was a wild animal, he did not know right from wrong in respect to this killing." Now, is that what happened --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- in effect? Or would -- did the judge say, "You may not introduce that evidence, because it is not relevant"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, fine. So, then, what is -- would -- if he thought it was a wild animal, then he would not have known right from wrong in respect to killing that individual.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, but whether it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I guess maybe the question is, What is your point? And I have the same question as Justice Breyer, and I'd just like to pursue that. If a case, a hypothetical case, is one in which the second prong of M'Naghten, knowing the difference in right and wrong, gets to the question of his capacity to form an intent, isn't that sufficient? I think that's Justice Breyer's question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But let's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but whether it does or

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- let's assume that it can 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- consider the evidence as to -- on the right-and-wrong prong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does the hypothetical state

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- that says, "We'll let this evidence" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- "in under the right-and - wrong aspect of M'Naghten, but not under the nature and quality of the act."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why that isn't sufficient to answer your contention that his intent is not -- has not been subject to question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What they said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'll look at M'Naghten. I had thought it was whether or not the action was right and wrong, whether -- rather than the -- than the -- than the moral command was wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then, what do you do --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then what you're saying, if I understand it, is that when the Arizona statute refers to whether or not the criminal act was wrong, the criminal act that they are referring to, on your view, is the act of intentional killing, period. And 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 if that's what they mean, then it is irrelevant that he thought he was killing a Martian. But if the Arizona reference to the criminal act being wrong refers to the act in this case -- i.e., killing somebody you believe is a Martian -- then the evidence could come in. So, I think your argument means -- your argument rests on the assumption that the Arizona statute's reference to the criminal act being wrong means the criminal act, in general, in the abstract -- i.e., intentional killing - - as distinct from the act of killing somebody you believe to be a Martian. Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, if that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But the Arizona Court, the Court of Appeals, writes that it turns on the finding of criminal responsibility at the time of the criminal offense. It is difficult to imagine that a defendant who did not appreciate the nature and quality of the act he committed would reasonably be able to perceive that the act was wrong. Now, those words, written by the Arizona Court, suggested to me that, in the case of the lemon you're talking about, or in the case of the individual who thinks that the truckdriver was a Martian, they would say he does not know right from wrong, here, now, in this case. That, it seemed to me, is what the Court of Appeals wrote.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if that's what they wrote, then they don't adopt the test you're attacking; rather, they do let the very evidence that you want to come in, come in, and it is totally relevant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- if Justice Breyer --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But if Justice --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- Breyer's explanation is a correct statement of Arizona law, do you still have an argument that your proof should have been accepted, on the first prong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what is that argument?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And your evidence to the contrary that was excluded would have showed what?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, it went to diminished mental capacity. And as I understand Arizona law, it has decided that that evidence can only be presented in the context of an insanity defense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the Constitution --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- requires a diminished- capacity defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, if you're going to let the evidence of diminished capacity in, on mens rea, you've done, by -- as it were, by the front door, what you can't do by the back door -- i.e., by a diminished- capacity defense -- because you're making the same point. The burdens of proof are different, but you're making the same point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do you -- do you think it is unconstitutional for a State to say, "We know perfectly well that it is much more difficult for both cognitive and reason -- reasons -- and reasons of character and training and so on, for some people to conform themselves to the criminal law than others. We know it's harder for some than others. But we don't care how much harder it is, unless it gets to the point that we define as insanity. Because unless we require 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 something as serious as insanity to excuse, everybody's going to have an excuse, and there isn't going to be any criminal law" -- is that unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Isn't that what the State does when it denies a diminished-capacity -- says, "We will not have a diminished-capacity defense"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. Now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- isn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but isn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: With respect, isn't that also what the State is getting at when it says, "We don't allow diminished-capacity evidence in on mens rea, which is the State's burden. Rather, we allow it in only on the defense of insanity, so that we can keep it clear, clear that unless the diminished capacity is so great as to amount to insanity, it's not an excuse"? And if that is what the State is doing, is there any - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- - anything unconstitutional about that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but it only --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- goes uncontested --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- it only goes uncontested if the only way you're going to contest it is to show diminished capacity. You could have contested this evidence by showing that, you know, he was a in a rock band, and he wanted to play the music for -- to advertise the concert, not to lure the police. There are a lot of defenses you can present. What they're saying is, if it goes to diminished capacity, that has to be used to show insanity or not - - or nothing at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Goldberg, may I ask you to clarify one thing about your argument? You say that you should have permitted -- been permitted to introduce this evidence to show that this act was not - - the "act" being, kill a police officer -- was not done intentionally or knowingly. But you seem to indicate that Clark could have been convicted, under the Arizona code, of some degree of murder. Am I right about that? And, if so, what degree?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And what would --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What was the second -- the definition of "second degree"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I just ask, what -- if the proof you'd like to introduce is that the defendant considered the police officer to be an alien, why would he have any intent? Why wouldn't your argument go, as well, to second degree?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it doesn't go to premeditation. I think that's Justice Ginsburg's point. And I don't see why that isn't correct. It doesn't got to premeditation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, but you're saying -- you're saying he could have been charged with second- degree murder --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- because -- what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does not require premeditation. And I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- don't see how this goes to premeditation, anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, suppose he did, he believed there -- it's an alien, which is not immoral, to kill an alien, let's say, if he comes from Mars. I don't know about the morality of that, but -- [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- I'll go with you. I'll say that you're absolutely right about that. Now, suppose, in addition, the judge did consider that. He did consider it, because he thought the person wouldn't know right from wrong if he thought this was an alien. All right? A space alien. Now, suppose that's true. Then what is the problem, from a due-process point of view? After all, you were able to make your claim there. The judge would have heard the evidence. And if the judge believed that that was so, he would have 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- acquitted the individual. Does there remain a due- process problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Actually, I was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, suppose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- I read State v. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- Mott --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it your argument that it -- under Arizona law, it goes to excuse the conduct, but not whether the conduct, in fact, occurred?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, is that your argument? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is that your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's a different question. If, in fact, it came in via the insanity defense, I guess the burden is on the defendant to prove it. Is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that true? Well, if it comes in via mens rea, then the burden is on the State to disprove it. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Doesn't the State have to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, if it came in via mens rea, that the mens rea was there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And so, the State --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- would have to show that, in fact, he was not so insane as to preclude intent.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Goldberg. Mr. Howe, we'll hear now from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, to prevail, do you think you have to show that, under prong two of M'Naghten, the right-and-wrong prong, that the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 defendant can prove really everything, and, in fact, did have the opportunity to prove everything, that he seeks to prove under prong one? If it's -- do you have to convince us of that in order to win?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But it's clear, Counsel, though, that the first prong of M'Naghten adds something different, "You don't understand the nature and quality of your acts." In other words, it would be enough, if you recognized both prongs, if he thought this was a Martian, regardless of whether he knew it was wrong to kill a Martian or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I am correct in assuming that it is -- and tell me if I'm wrong -- that it is your position, the State's position, that, under the right/wrong prong-two part of M'Naghten, and under the evidence in this case, the court was able to consider, really, all of the evidence that's necessary in order to meet this defendant's defense as to -- as to intent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I agree with you. I'm trying to think of some theoretical case where it would make a difference. I can't quite come up with a hypothetical. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, wouldn't it make a difference in a case in which an individual understands, number one, as a general matter, that it is wrong to kill people intentionally? He also believes that there are space aliens. And he believes that it is wrong to kill space aliens. But he kills one. Under the full M'Naghten test, under prong one, he would have a defense. But under the M'Naghten test of prong two alone, since he believed it was wrong to kill Martians, he wouldn't have a defense. Isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Counsel, I'm puzzled about 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 one thing. I just -- maybe it's just my stupidity. But assume he thought it was a Martian, and assume he thought -- does he have to think it was wrong to kill Martians? Or supposing he thinks it is not wrong to kill Martians, then what do you do? Does it matter whether he thinks it's right or wrong to kill Martians, in other words?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm not sure I understand the answer. I -- that -- is it -- does he -- let me put it this way, and maybe you can answer yes or no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Does he have to think it's wrong to kill Martians?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The thing that troubles me, just to -- and then you can comment on it -- I'm assuming it's possible they thought he didn't know whether it was a Martian or not, and that he thought he had a mission in life to kill Martians, that they're enemies, they're bad to come, and he wants to kill 'em. If that was the -- what the trial court found, could he be put to death for that killing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Or could he just be found guilty of murder, or whatever, on those facts?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, but there's a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- difference in the burden of proof. He has the burden of proof to get the affirmative defense or to get the -- in that category.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And I'm just wondering if he's -- just raises a doubt as -- so there's not proof beyond a reasonable doubt that he knew the person he was killing was either a human being or an -- a kind of individual that it would be wrong to kill.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If there's just a reasonable doubt on the issue --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- would he be guilty, or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But, as you say, it's -- in a way, it's -- in a sense, it comes in through the back door, as you say, but, even coming in through the back door, if it raises a reasonable doubt as to his intent to kill a -- make a wrongful killing, why shouldn't it be admissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does that mean that it could also exclude the testimony from the lay people or the friends who talked about this person's illness?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Or are we just talking about the expert testimony?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Howe, would you explain to me how the State has proved intentional -- not intentional killing, but of a police officer? If that's the charge, that he intended to kill a police officer, how does the State meet its burden on a police officer if the testimony on the other side is, "I did not understand that this human that I killed was a police officer"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I see that on the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the State side, so the State has introduced evidence from which a trier could conclude he intended to kill a police officer. But he 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 wants to introduce, on the other side, "I didn't have that intent. In fact, I had delusions. I thought I killed an alien." But he's not allowed to introduce that evidence --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- to counter --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the State's proof, as I understand what the Arizona law is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is this an alternative argument, so that, if we accept this argument, we need not ask whether the evidence comes in under prong two, or is this complementary to the argument that the evidence comes in under prong two?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Why is that, Counsel? Let's suppose that the -- one of the cases that come up is a language difficulty. The individual -- maybe he's not in uniform -- identifies himself as a police officer. Could the State have a rule that, "We are not going to allow evidence of language concerns," that the individual didn't speak English, and the officer said, "I'm a police officer," so he didn't know, when he shot him? What is it about mental capacity that allows you to exclude that type of evidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Howe, one of the things that puzzled me about your position is, you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 said, "Under Arizona law, while this doesn't come in under mens rea, it does affect sentencing." I think you said that the -- his mental state is properly taken into account in the sentencing. And, by that, did you mean just the length of the incarceration, or the place of the incarceration?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You can -- may answer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Howe. General Clement, we'll hear now from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could the State say that it's the defendant's burden to show that it was not a police officer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because the next question is, Why didn't they -- isn't that what happened here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me that you introduced the -- my concern by saying that they -- the State can put the burden of proof on the defendant, which we know is generally true in many States with reference to the insanity defense. But when you link it with mens rea, then it seems to me you have a problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It does seem as if the argument, that, "Oh, this all comes in under second -- under the second prong," means that if there's a -- there's another inference. It's a -- it's a secondhand argument about lack of mens rea.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Kind of, the second-class --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- sort of evidence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That would present a serious constitutional question, wouldn't it? Or what -- I mean, I -- that's -- but I thought some of these questions might be in this case, but I now doubt -- I'm having doubts about that. But suppose the State so limits the defense that an individual defendant, who, by any ordinary psychiatric test, would be viewed as seriously insane, and, therefore, not a person who is capable of being held responsible in any moral sense for the crime, is, nonetheless, going to be convicted of murder? I mean -- and that might be -- come up with irresistible impulse, because the person is totally insane, not like any other human being. Anyone would normally say he lacked the knowledge of -- he's not responsible for what he does. And then, the State, nonetheless, convicts him of murder.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If he knew right from wrong, if they -- so, I mean, he -- it's not his intellectual capacity that's wrong, it's his ability to control his impulse.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that's not in this case, I agree with you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But is a variation of that in this case -- namely, the variation -- but we've discussed that at length, and I take it you think that's not in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But we don't have to reach that question here, in your view.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Or do we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if we have to reach it, this -- they're arguing we do, because they're saying the person is so insane he doesn't know whether this is a human being or a sack of lemons. Now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- he said that they didn't consider that in the insanity defense. And he's not attacking the burden of proof, at least not in this Court. And so, I -- do you think we do have to -- that we have to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- assume that he's right on that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is "diminished 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 capacity," if it is -- what is that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But partial responsibility does not -- insanity -- they use the words "insanity" and "diminished responsibility." I took the word "insanity" to mean the kind of mental state that would, in fact, show a lack of intent. I took the word "diminished responsibility" to mean there is intent, but it's excusable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, am I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- this question? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- Supposing the evidence is equally divided on the question of whether he thought it was a Martian who he had a right to kill. Could he be convicted of murder, constitutionally?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because then --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- there would be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- not proof beyond a reasonable doubt that he knew he was killing a human being, and it was wrong to do so.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, I don't -- I don't -- I'm just wondering, as a constitutional matter, forgetting all the -- as a constitutional matter, can a man be convicted of murder if the evidence is equally balanced on the question of whether he knew it -- he did anything wrong and -- or knew that he was killing a human being?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Have we ever held that an insanity defense is required, that a State cannot simply abolish insanity defenses?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't we had.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, is a State required to adopt any particular mens rea for murder? Is there a constitutional requirement as to the minimum mens rea that can be -- can be set for the offense of murder?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But here, there --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- was a charge, "intended to kill a police officer." It could have been just 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- "intended to kill." And I think Mr. Goldberg conceded that "intended to kill" would have been a proper conviction, but not "intended to kill a police officer"

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- unless he's allowed to counter that add-on.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General. Mr. Goldberg, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that certainly doesn't include the right to present any evidence you want.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You couldn't have presented evidence that this person was, in fact, a Martian.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Was it a reasonable question whether he knew it was a police officer or whether he knew it was a human being?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, I -- the best I can find in that Court of Appeals opinion, at the moment, is that they do reject the idea of diminished responsibility, on Mott -- on the ground of Mott. That's true. They say, "Don't even consider it." But I didn't think diminished responsibility went to the question of whether he had the requisite intent. I thought insanity went to that, as they use those words. What is "diminished responsibility," if it isn't, "We admit the intent -- we admit that he intended to kill the individual, knew it was wrong, but he isn't as responsible as an ordinary person would be"? What is - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- it, if it isn't that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He thought he was killing another individual.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does the State have to -- does the Constitution have to let you off if that's the situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- but does the State have to say, "We are going to convict you of a lesser offense," in the Constitution?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 12:04 p.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.] 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400
